title: April 2017 Licensure Exam: Paper Four
description: Comprehensive licensure examination covering Mental Health, Community Health, Management, and Teaching methodology.

questions.question: What is the correct loading dose for quinine therapy in severe malaria for an 8 Kg infant?

options.text: 40 mg
80 mg
100 mg
160 mg

questions.explanation: The standard loading dose for Quinine in severe malaria is 20 mg salt/kg. For an 8 kg infant: 20 mg × 8 kg = 160 mg. The maintenance dose is typically 10 mg/kg every 8 hours.
questions.hint: Calculate using the standard loading dose formula of 20 mg/kg.

questions.question: While caring for a 3 year old child admitted with asthma, what would be the priority nursing intervention?

options.text: Performing nebulization with albuterol upto 6 doses in the first hour
Giving humidified oxygen via nasal prongs titrated by oximetry
Chest physiotherapy after every nebulization till discharge
Administer prescribed cough suppressants to improve child’s comfort

questions.explanation: In acute asthma exacerbation, relieving bronchoconstriction is the priority to improve airway patency. Short-acting beta-agonists (like Albuterol) via nebulization are the first-line treatment. Chest physiotherapy and cough suppressants are generally contraindicated in acute asthma.
questions.hint: Focus on the intervention that directly addresses airway bronchoconstriction.

questions.question: What is a correct discharge instruction to parents of a 12 month old infant with gastro-esophageal reflux disease?

options.text: Give the infant blended thinned feeds for easy digestion
Watch for blood-stained vomitus which requires urgent medical attention
Give prescribed proton-pump inhibitors such as ranitidine to inhibit gastric acid secretion
Surgical management is the ultimate intervention for consideration

questions.explanation: Parents must be educated on warning signs (red flags) such as hematemesis (blood-stained vomit), which indicates complications like esophagitis or bleeding. Feeds should typically be thickened, not thinned.
questions.hint: Identify the 'red flag' sign that would indicate a serious complication.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding HIV-exposed infants is true?

options.text: BCG vaccine is contraindicated in all HIV-exposed babies
A HIV-exposed infant should be immediately started on ARV therapy irrespective of clinical staging once PCR test is confirmed positive
BCG vaccine should be delayed until HIV status is confirmed negative
ARV therapy is only started after clinical staging indicates symptoms

questions.explanation: Under 'Test and Treat' guidelines, any infant with a confirmed positive PCR for HIV should start ART immediately, regardless of CD4 count or clinical stage. BCG is given to HIV-exposed infants unless they show signs of symptomatic HIV infection.
questions.hint: Think about the 'Test and Treat' strategy for infants.

questions.question: Which statement regarding primary irritant diaper dermatitis is correct?

options.text: The affected area is most commonly colorized by candida albicans
Lesions appear as discrete follicular papules
The treatment of choice is low potency topical steroids
Plastic pants should be used in preference to diapers

questions.explanation: Low potency topical steroids (like 1% hydrocortisone) are used to reduce inflammation in irritant dermatitis. Candida (options A & B) presents with satellite lesions and involves skin folds. Plastic pants worsen the condition.
questions.hint: Distinguish between primary irritant dermatitis and fungal (Candida) infection.

questions.question: According to Erickson’s developmental theory, what is the developmental task during the 'stage of industry versus inferiority'?

options.text: Develop a sense of purpose and ability to initiate and direct own activities
Gain some self-control and independence within the environment
Achieve life goals established for oneself while considering welfare of future generations
Achieve a sense of self-confidence by learning, completing and receiving recognition from others

questions.explanation: Industry vs. Inferiority covers school age (6-12 years). The task is to develop social and academic skills, leading to a sense of competence (industry). Option A is Initiative vs Guilt; B is Autonomy vs Shame.
questions.hint: This stage corresponds to the school-age years where learning and skills are paramount.

questions.question: Phenothiazines are thought to exert their antipsychotic effect by:

options.text: Blocking post-synaptic dopamine receptors in the basal ganglia
Enhancing dopamine-mediated transmission of neural impulses at the synapses
Altering sodium metabolism within muscle cells and nerves
Selectively inhibiting the re-uptake of amines such as nor-epinephrine

questions.explanation: Phenothiazines (typical antipsychotics) primarily work by blocking dopamine D2 receptors in the brain's mesolimbic and nigrostriatal pathways.
questions.hint: Antipsychotics generally antagonize which specific neurotransmitter?

questions.question: What is the priority nursing diagnosis for a 14 year old teenager admitted with Bulimia nervosa?

options.text: Body image disturbance related to retarded ego development
Ineffective denial related to fear of losing an aspect of life she has control over
High risk for fluid deficit related to abuse of laxatives and diuretics
Disturbed self esteem related to dysfunctional family system

questions.explanation: Physiological safety is the priority (Maslow's hierarchy). Bulimia involves purging which leads to severe electrolyte imbalances and dehydration, which can be life-threatening.
questions.hint: Apply Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs: Physiological safety comes first.

questions.question: In Korsakoff’s psychosis:

options.text: Thiamine deficiency results in pain, burning and tingling sensation in the extremities
Symptoms of palpitations, anxiety, diaphoresis and arrhythmias occur
The resultant symptoms of confusion, confabulation and memory loss occur due to azotemia
Treatment requires parenteral or oral Thiamine plus complete alcohol abstinence

questions.explanation: Korsakoff's psychosis is caused by severe Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, typically from alcohol abuse. It presents with confusion, confabulation, and memory loss. Treatment involves Thiamine replacement and alcohol abstinence.
questions.hint: Identify the nutritional deficiency and the required treatment.

questions.question: Which of the following are prominent symptoms of schizophrenia during the residual phase?

options.text: Flat affect, impaired role functioning, social withdrawal
Eccentric peculiar behavior, bizarre delusions, neglect of personal hygiene
Hallucinations, loosening of association, lack of initiative
Catatonic behavior, incoherence, bizarre ideas

questions.explanation: The residual phase follows the active phase. Positive symptoms (hallucinations, delusions) have subsided, but negative symptoms (flat affect, withdrawal, lack of volition) persist.
questions.hint: Think about 'negative' symptoms that remain after the 'positive' storm has passed.

questions.question: A development achievement in a five month old infant is demonstrated when the child:

options.text: Uses simple words such as ‘mama’
Uses monosyllabic babbling
Links syllables together
Coos when comforted

questions.explanation: By 4-6 months, infants begin to babble using consonant-vowel combinations (monosyllabic babbling). Cooing is earlier (2 months), and linking syllables/words is later.
questions.hint: At 5 months, the infant is past cooing but not yet speaking words.

questions.question: What action should a ward manager take when a staff nurse has stolen ward drugs?

options.text: Give the nurse a verbal warning
Notify the police in the nearby station
Report the case to the hospital nurse in-charge
Dismiss the nurse immediately from the work station

questions.explanation: The immediate line of reporting is to the hospital administration/Nurse In-Charge. Ward managers typically lack authority for summary dismissal. Theft is too serious for just a verbal warning but requires following protocol before police involvement.
questions.hint: Follow the chain of command for serious administrative issues.

questions.question: Future oriented statements that are purposefully designed to identify the derived future of an organization are referred to as:

options.text: Organizational structure
Philosophy
Mission
Vision

questions.explanation: A Vision Statement describes where the organization wants to be in the future. A Mission Statement describes the organization's current purpose.
questions.hint: Think of the word that relates to 'seeing' the future.

questions.question: When preparing a teaching plan, the nurse describes what the learner will be able to accomplish after the teaching session. This action is:

options.text: Developing learning objective
Providing practice reinforcement
Implementing interpersonal communication
Presenting facts and knowledge

questions.explanation: A learning objective is a specific statement that describes what the learner will be able to do or demonstrate after instruction.
questions.hint: What defines the specific outcome of a lesson?

questions.question: A student learns that the normal adult heartbeat is 60 to 100 beats/minute. Which domain did learning take place?

options.text: Cognitive
Kinesthetic
Affective
Psychomotor

questions.explanation: The Cognitive domain involves knowledge, facts, and intellectual skills. Remembering a heart rate range is a cognitive task.
questions.hint: This domain relates to 'thinking' and 'knowing' facts.

questions.question: Which factor should the nurse assess to determine a patient's ability to learn?

options.text: Socio cultural background
Overall physical health
Developmental capabilities
Psychosocial adaptation

questions.explanation: The *ability* to learn is most directly determined by developmental stage, cognitive function, and physical capacity (developmental capabilities). Other factors affect readiness or motivation.
questions.hint: Which option most directly relates to the *capacity* to process information?

questions.question: The validity of a written examination can be guaranteed by:

options.text: Developing a comprehensive marking key
Ensuring a well-balanced content examination
Subjecting written scripts to more than one examiner for marking
Offering candidates a chance for a re-test

questions.explanation: Validity refers to whether the test measures what it intends to measure (content validity). This is guaranteed by a well-balanced distribution of content (Table of Specifications). Multiple examiners (Option C) ensures reliability.
questions.hint: Validity is about content coverage; Reliability is about consistency.

questions.question: The use of question and answer in microteaching skill:

options.text: Helps to diagnose learners’ strengths and weaknesses
Often assists the teacher to grade learners at the end of the course
Requires the teacher to know answers to all questions
Should particularly focus on struggling learners to improve their performance

questions.explanation: Questioning skills in microteaching are used to assess understanding, stimulate thinking, and diagnose learning gaps (strengths/weaknesses).
questions.hint: What is the diagnostic purpose of asking questions in class?

questions.question: Which of the following are individual differences that influence learning?

options.text: Complexity of content, language ability, age
Value of subject content, provision for practice, ethnicity
Past experiences, educational background, marital status
Employment status, ethnicity, educational background

questions.explanation: Individual differences refer to characteristics inherent to the learner. Past experiences and educational background are key learner-centric variables. Complexity of content (Option A) is a task variable.
questions.hint: Look for the option that lists characteristics specific to the *learner's* history and status.

questions.question: When a learner conducts a bedside presentation of a selected patient to fellow learners and the instructor, this is termed:

options.text: Nursing conference
Nursing case study
Nursing clinical round
Nursing clinic

questions.explanation: A Nursing Case Study presentation involves a detailed presentation of a single patient's history and care plan. A clinical round typically involves visiting multiple patients.
questions.hint: Focus on the detailed presentation of a *selected* patient.

questions.question: Which of the following are diagnostic criteria symptoms of delirium? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Disturbance in attention (reduced ability to focus)
Acute onset and fluctuating course
Disorganized thinking
Disturbance in consciousness
Gradual onset over months
Intact memory and orientation

questions.explanation: Delirium is characterized by acute onset, fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and disturbance in consciousness. Gradual onset suggests dementia.
questions.hint: Remember the key difference between delirium (acute) and dementia (chronic).

questions.question: What are the primary goals of rehabilitation for mentally ill persons? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Restoration of independent functioning
Prevention of relapse
Community integration
Complete cure of the illness
Permanent institutionalization

questions.explanation: Goals include restoring function, preventing relapse, and integrating into the community. Many mental illnesses are chronic, so 'complete cure' is not always the goal; management is.
questions.hint: Think about helping the patient return to a normal life.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of a good clinical instructor? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Clinically competent and knowledgeable
Approachable and supportive
Effective communicator
Strict and authoritarian
Patient and understanding

questions.explanation: Good instructors are knowledgeable, approachable, effective communicators, and patient. Authoritarianism hinders the learning relationship.
questions.hint: Select traits that foster a positive learning environment.

questions.question: What are the advantages of group discussion as a teaching strategy? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Promotes active participation
Develops critical thinking skills
Facilitates peer learning
Improves communication skills
Allows teacher to lecture without interruption

questions.explanation: Group discussion encourages active participation, critical thinking, peer learning, and communication. It is interactive, not a lecture method.
questions.hint: Think about student engagement and skill development.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of the decision-making process in the correct logical order:
questions.explanation: The logical flow is: Define Problem -> Collect Data -> Weigh Options -> Choose -> Act & Check.
questions.hint: You must know what the problem is before you can solve it.

questions.question: Order the categories of Bloom's Cognitive Domain from lowest to highest complexity:
questions.explanation: The traditional hierarchy is Knowledge (recall) -> Comprehension -> Application -> Analysis -> Synthesis -> Evaluation.
questions.hint: Start with basic recall and end with judgment/evaluation.

questions.question: Identify risk factors for infective endocarditis in children. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Congenital Heart Disease (CHD)
Rheumatic Heart Disease
Indwelling central venous catheters
Invasive dental or surgical procedures
Absence of structural heart defects

questions.explanation: Risk factors involve structural heart defects (CHD, Rheumatic damage) or portals of entry for bacteria (catheters, invasive procedures).
questions.hint: Think about conditions that damage heart valves or introduce bacteria into the blood.

questions.question: Select the appropriate nursing responsibilities when caring for a child with febrile convulsions. (Select all that apply)

options.text: Maintain airway (side-lying position)
Ensure safety (pad rails, remove hard objects)
Manage fever (antipyretics, tepid sponging)
Restrain the child to stop movements
Force open the mouth to insert a spatula

questions.explanation: Priorities are Airway, Safety, and Fever management. Never restrain a convulsing child or force objects into their mouth.
questions.hint: Do NOT restrain or put objects in the mouth.

questions.question: Case Study: Madam V (24yo) has Anxious (Avoidant) Personality Disorder. Select the correct diagnostic criteria and management approaches.

richContent.content:
Patient: Madam V, 24 years old

Diagnosis: Anxious (Avoidant) Personality Disorder

Presentation: History of pervasive social inhibition and hypersensitivity to negative comments.

options.text: Diagnostic: Preoccupied with being criticized or rejected in social situations
Diagnostic: Views self as socially inept or inferior
Management: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) to challenge negative thoughts
Management: Social Skills Training
Diagnostic: Excessive need for admiration and lack of empathy
Management: Isolation from all social contact

questions.explanation: Avoidant PD involves fear of rejection and feelings of inadequacy. Management focuses on building confidence and skills (CBT, Social Skills Training). Option E describes Narcissistic PD.
questions.hint: Match the symptoms to the 'Avoidant' nature of the disorder.

questions.question: Scenario: You are appointed as a Ward Manager. Which of the following accurately describe your responsibilities and objectives?

richContent.content:
Role: Ward Manager in a newly established sub-county hospital.

Goal: Apply management knowledge for effective patient care.

options.text: Planning: Setting goals and duty rotas
Organizing: Assigning duties according to competence
Directing: Supervising and motivating staff
Resource Management: Ordering supplies and preventing wastage
Disregarding student training to focus only on patients
Avoiding conflict resolution to maintain peace

questions.explanation: Ward management involves Planning, Organizing, Directing, and Controlling. Responsibilities include resource management, staff supervision, and conflict resolution.
questions.hint: Select the core functions of management (PODC).
